bioghist.p: Villanova University traces its origins to old Saint Augustine's Church in Philadelphia, which the Augustinians founded in 1796, and to its parish school, Saint Augustine's Academy, established in 1811. Villanova University has been sponsored by the Augustinian Order since its founding in 1842. Today, the University is comprised of five colleges: Liberal Arts and Sciences (Villanova College), Engineering, School of Business (formerly known as the College of Commerce and Finance), Nursing and the School of Law. Over the course of Villanova's history, the University's library had been housed in several buildings. A new library building was erected after World War II, and in 1963 it was named and rededicated in honor of Father Daniel P. Falvey, who was instrumental in the development of the Library and its collections.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of records of the Falvey Memorial Library of Villanova University. Administrative records include library policies, receipts for book purchases (1877-1937), forms, and lists of Library staff (1985-1990). Correspondence dates from 1888 to 2000. Topics addressed in the Correspondence files include professional associations, automation, exhibitions, expansion and building issues, installation of a circulation system, and correspondence of Rev. Daniel P. Falvey (1950-1984), James A. Farley (1943-1959), Joseph McGarrrity (1940-1948), Rev. Thomas C. Middleton (1888-1923), Rev. Francis E. Tourscher (1902-1941), and others. Legal records include information regarding appraisals and a 1968 federal loan for the Library. Minutes are present for meetings of the Faculty Library Committee (1954-2000), Library Department Heads (1969-1985), staff meetings, and several other committees and councils. The News Media series includes newspaper clippings and articles on the library, its collections, and several notable members of the Library staff. The Personal Papers series includes articles by and about several Library staff members (including Daniel P. Falvey, Francis Tourscher, Thomas C. Middleton, and Louis A. Rongione), awards, bibliographies, and ephemera. Printed materials and programs include exhibition brochures, invitations, and articles on the Library and its directors. Reports in the collection include building and facilities studies and proposals, annual reports (1962-2000), library manuals, circulation system proposals and agreements, acquisitions, and a 1949 history of the Library. The collection also includes records of the Friends of the Library. These materials consist of correspondence; minutes of the Friends of the Library Executive Committee (1947-1960); newsletters (1954); news clippings and press releases; programs and ephemera; and addresses. Volumes in the collection include: book catalog, 1894; circulation ledger, 1902-1923; library accession books 1898-1908; 1903-1907, 1934-1938; and a printed volume of Augustinus: Civitate Dei, 1838.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
